posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Especially importantly, does anyone know if the internal algorithms for pose estimation that run on Limitless devices are publicly available? I've been searching extensively but haven't found anything conclusive. For my summer project, I aim to enhance the MegaTag 1/2 algorithms, and I'm curious about the level of optimizations, filters, or features currently utilized beneath the hood.

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked:
Here's the cleaned-up version of your text:

No, the limelight is off, but PhotonVision's constrained PnP solver is quite similar, and the entire project is open source, utilized by many teams.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: Carlos Salazar
posts.cooked:
Limelight does not use a PnP algorithm to solve for robot poses on the field. Instead, it employs a trigonometric algorithm based on the square geometry of AprilTags.

PnP, or Perspective-n-Point, is a computer vision technique used to estimate an object's pose by matching 3D points to their 2D projections. It is flexible, accurate, and handles edge cases well but is computationally intensive.

The trigonometric method leverages the known square geometry of AprilTags and applies direct trigonometric relationships to estimate pose. It assumes the tag lies flat and requires camera calibration. This approach is faster and more efficient for real-time use on embedded systems like Limelight.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: With some optimizations to the algorithm, based on a team’s use case, could you get a trigonometric solver to work at a higher accuracy level than PnP?

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Limelight does not use a PnP algorithm for solving robot poses on the field; instead, it employs a trigonometric approach. Several references to pnp exist in the Limelight documentation, though. What is your source?

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: The Limelight system shares a general concept with PV, an open-source vision library for coprocessors, and other vision systems, but it excels in corner detection and pose filtering. Unlike most vision systems in FIRST Robotics Competition, which rely on OpenCV ArUco detection (faster but less stable), Limelight's corner detection is highly stable with a low standard deviation. A notable feature of Limelight 3G or 3 is its superior corner detection reliability, achievable through either the AprilTag3 library or a custom optimized version, though it sacrifices some speed for enhanced stability. The camera-to-processor connection via CSI ensures lower compression and sharper image edges compared to USB2. Regarding pose filtering, the SolvePnP algorithm provides a ranked list of potential positions based on re-projection error. However, due to potential inaccuracies in corner detection, this metric may not fully reflect pose precision. LL4 employs an internal gyro and height alongside re-projection error to determine the optimal robot pose, whereas LL3 and LL3G use timestamps in NT to adjust for latency during pose determination.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: That makes sense. What I'm currently working on is developing a solver that uses gyro readings along with data from a Limelight 3G connected via NetworkTables. This project aims to address several shortcomings observed this year—such as trusting tag position information more when they're close rather than far, implementing custom confidence levels for individual tags instead of discarding unused tag data, and utilizing gyroscopic information to resolve ambiguities without completely ignoring measured angles. Additionally, this solver offers more flexibility for real-time adjustments on the Rio side. The trade-off of potentially sacrificing some fine-tuning and hidden optimizations from the current setup might be worthwhile if it allows for tighter control over specific aspects.

posts.name: Carlos Salazar
posts.cooked: Limelight’s pipelines have evolved significantly, particularly with the introduction of MT2, which represents a shift to more advanced vision algorithms that go beyond trigonometric shortcuts. The original statement that Limelight doesn’t use PnP was an oversimplification. Instead, MT1 relies on direct angular and area measurements based on trigonometric estimations, making it ideal for embedded systems. However, MT1 struggles with stability at long distances or oblique angles, as demonstrated by a GIF showing its instability compared to MT2. MT2, described as providing excellent pose estimates regardless of perspective and robust to physical AprilTag placement inaccuracies, likely employs a PnP-based or hybrid solver. These algorithms minimize reprojection error to handle perspective distortion and uncertainties effectively. Thanks to @Joe_Ross for challenging my earlier statement, highlighting the significant advancements in Limelight’s pipelines.

link_counts.title: Robot Localization with MegaTag2 | Limelight Documentation

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked:
Em, I think LL (Limelight, an integrated vision coprocessor) is using PNP to determine the angle of the tag, and they use a gyroscope to disambiguate. The issue you mentioned might involve latency or gyro offset. Regarding weight, I believe PNP doesn’t assign weights to each point. Instead, using algorithms like RANSAC could help eliminate outliers by randomly sampling corners and calculating results based on the least re-projection error.  

Additionally, running advanced algorithms on RoboRIO isn’t ideal due to its limited computing power. I think LL provides programmable features using Python, which may be more effective than running similar algorithms on RoboRIO, thanks to its embedded OpenCV and numpy libraries.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: I thought that the only computationally expensive part of vision was running the ML model

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: These algorithms aren't considered computationally intensive normally. Yet, because RoboRIO has limited processing power and already runs the robot's software, these algorithms might interfere with its main thread. Also, doing linear algebra in Java can be inefficient due to poor memory access, which might slow down the main thread unnoticed. On the other hand, Jumpy and OpenCV execute their code in C++ with significant optimizations.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: We’re a Python team, so we might be able to easily wrap some c++ code.

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: Its important to note that both Photon Vision and Limelight utilize the UMitch detector, although Photon Vision is additionally capable of using ArUco.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: The computational expense of the AprilTag detection and pose estimation on VEX ROBORIO v1 consumes 80% of the CPU, making it impractical for v1 hardware while being feasible for v2.
